briefOverview: Ben Sira extols Simon son of Onias, the high priest, portraying the splendor of temple worship under his leadership and concluding with a communal blessing, denunciation of hostile peoples, and an authorial epilogue.
summary: The chapter praises Simon the high priest for strengthening the temple, enlarging the city, and improving its entrances, even likening his radiance and office to celestial and natural splendors. It vividly describes a temple service: Simon vested in sacred garments, receiving portions, offering libations of wine, incense, and sacrifices, while priests trumpet, singers chant psalms, and the people prostrate in prayer. After completing the offerings, Simon blesses the assembly and prays for joy, peace, and God’s mercy upon Israel. The author then names two nations he hates—those on Mount Seir (Edom) and the Philistines—and a third group he calls “not a nation,” the foolish people of Shechem. The chapter closes identifying the author as Jesus son of Sirach of Jerusalem, blessing those who keep the teachings of wisdom contained in the book.
externalContext: “Jesus son of Sirach” (Ben Sira) composed this wisdom work in Jerusalem in the early second century BCE; his grandson later translated it into Greek around 132 BCE. The “Simon son of Onias” praised here is commonly identified by scholars as Simon II (early second century BCE), though a minority view proposes Simon I; the text itself does not specify which. In the Second Temple period, the high priest was both religious head and a crucial civic leader, overseeing cultic order and often public works, including fortifications and water supply—hence the note about abundant waters. The richly detailed liturgical scene reflects regular sacrificial worship with priests, Levites, trumpets, incense, psalmody, and congregational prostration. The “foolish people who live at Shechem” likely refers to Samaritans centered near Mount Gerizim, reflecting strained Judean–Samaritan relations in the Hellenistic era.
externalReferences: The portrayal of the high priest’s garments and glory echoes the high priestly vestments and sanctity described in Exodus 28:2–4 and the honor of Aaron’s line celebrated in Sirach 45:6–22. The trumpets and memorial sounding during offerings recall Numbers 10:10, while the priestly blessing with uplifted hands resonates with the Aaronic blessing pattern in Numbers 6:22–27. The “blood of the grape” as libation corresponds to wine offerings and language found in Deuteronomy 32:14. The rainbow and other creation images that magnify Simon’s appearance allude to God’s covenantal sign in Genesis 9:13, situating the high priest’s ministry within broader covenant symbolism.
practicalQuestions: How does communal worship—with music, ritual, and posture—shape a people’s reverence toward God today?
What responsibilities should spiritual leaders assume in caring for civic well-being, as Simon is portrayed doing?
How can prayers for national peace and mercy (vv. 24–26) be voiced without fostering hostility toward other groups (vv. 27–28)?
What practices help modern communities bless and encourage one another after shared worship?
In what ways can honoring faithful leaders avoid slipping into uncritical hero-worship?
uncertainAreas: Which Simon son of Onias is intended (I or II) is debated; the text does not specify. The precise festival or occasion of the described service is not identified. The reference to “foolish people who live at Shechem” likely indicates Samaritans, but the text does not name them directly. The note about waters may reflect literal public works, metaphor, or both.
